Text: a promise that she had done gay, exciting things just a while since and that there were gay, exciting things hovering in the next hour.  I told her how I had stopped off in Chicago for a day on my way East, and how a dozen people had sent their love through me.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “The whole town is desolate. All the cars have the left rear wheel painted black as a mourning wreath, and there’s a persistent wail all night along the north shore.”
Speaker: Nick

Text: “How gorgeous! Let’s go back, Tom. Tomorrow!”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: “She’s asleep. She’s three years old. Haven’t you ever seen her?”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: “Well, you ought to see her. She’s—”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: Tom Buchanan, who had been hovering restlessly about the room, stopped and rested his hand on my shoulder.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: he remarked decisively.  This annoyed me.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “You will if you stay in the East.”
Speaker: Nick

Text: “Oh, I’ll stay in the East, don’t you worry,”
Speaker: Tom

Text: he said, glancing at Daisy and then back at me, as if he were alert for something more.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “I’d be a God damned fool to live anywhere else.”
Speaker: Tom

Text: At this point Miss Baker said:
Speaker: Narrator

Text: with such suddenness that I started—it was the first word she had uttered since I came into the room. Evidently it surprised her as much as it did me, for she yawned and with a series of rapid, deft movements stood up into the room.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “I’ve been lying on that sofa for as long as I can remember.”
Speaker: Jordan

Text: “I’ve been trying to get you to New York all afternoon.”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: said Miss Baker to the four cocktails just in from the pantry.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: Her host looked at her incredulously.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: He took down his drink as if it were a drop in the bottom of a glass.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “How you ever get anything done is beyond me.”
Speaker: Tom

Text: I looked at Miss Baker, wondering what it was she
Speaker: Narrator

Text: I enjoyed looking at her. She was a slender, small-breasted girl, with an erect carriage, which she accentuated by throwing her body backward at the shoulders like a young cadet. Her grey sun-strained eyes looked back at me with polite reciprocal curiosity out of a wan, charming, discontented face. It occurred to me now that I had seen her, or a picture of her, somewhere before.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: Before I could reply that he was my neighbour dinner was announced; wedging his tense arm imperatively under mine, Tom Buchanan compelled me from the room as though he were moving a checker to another square.  Slenderly, languidly, their hands set lightly on their hips, the two young women preceded us out on to a rosy-coloured porch, open toward the sunset, where four candles flickered on the table in the diminished wind.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: objected Daisy, frowning. She snapped them out with her fingers.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “In two weeks it’ll be the longest day in the year.”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: She looked at us all radiantly.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “Do you always watch for the longest day of the year and then miss it? I always watch for the longest day in the year and then miss it.”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: yawned Miss Baker, sitting down at the table as if she were getting into bed.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: Before I could answer her eyes fastened with an awed expression on her little finger.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: We all looked—the knuckle was black and blue.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “I know you didn’t mean to, but you did do it. That’s what I get for marrying a brute of a man, a great, big, hulking physical specimen of a—”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: insisted Daisy.  Sometimes she and Miss Baker talked at once, unobtrusively and with a bantering inconsequence that was never quite chatter, that was as cool as their white dresses and their impersonal eyes in the absence of all desire. They were here, and they accepted Tom and me, making only a polite pleasant effort to entertain or to be entertained. They knew that presently dinner would be over and a little later the evening too would be over and casually put away. It was sharply different from the West, where an evening was hurried from phase to phase towards its close, in a continually disappointed anticipation or else in sheer nervous dread of the moment itself.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: I confessed on my second glass of corky but rather impressive claret.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “Can’t you talk about crops or something?”
Speaker: Nick

Text: I meant nothing in particular by this remark, but it was taken up in an unexpected way.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “I’ve gotten to be a terrible pessimist about things. Have you read The Rise of the Coloured Empires by this man Goddard?”
Speaker: Tom

Text: I answered, rather surprised by his tone.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “Well, it’s a fine book, and everybody ought to read it. The idea is if we don’t look out the white race will be—will be utterly submerged. It’s all scientific stuff; it’s been proved.”
Speaker: Tom

Text: said Daisy, with an expression of unthoughtful sadness.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “He reads deep books with long words in them. What was that word we—”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: insisted Tom, glancing at her impatiently.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “This fellow has worked out the whole thing. It’s up to us, who are the dominant race, to watch out or these other races will have control of things.”
Speaker: Tom

Text: whispered Daisy, winking ferociously toward the fervent sun.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: began Miss Baker, but Tom interrupted her by shifting heavily in his chair.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “This idea is that we’re Nordics. I am, and you are, and you are, and—”
Speaker: Tom

Text: After an infinitesimal hesitation he included Daisy with a slight nod, and she winked at me again.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “—And we’ve produced all the things that go to make civilization—oh, science and art, and all that. Do you see?”
Speaker: Tom

Text: There was something pathetic in his concentration, as if his complacency, more acute than of old, was not enough to him any more. When, almost immediately, the telephone rang inside and the butler left the porch Daisy seized upon the momentary interruption and leaned towards me.
Speaker: Narrator

Text: “It’s about the butler’s nose. Do you want to hear about the butler’s nose?”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: “Well, he wasn’t always a butler; he used to be the silver polisher for some people in New York that had a silver service for two hundred people. He had to polish it from morning till night, until finally it began to affect his nose—”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: “Yes. Things went from bad to worse, until finally he had to give up his position.”
Speaker: Daisy

Text: For a moment the last sunshine fell with romantic affection upon her glowing face; her voice compelled me forward breathlessly as I listened—then the glow faded, each light deserting her with lingering regret, like children leaving a pleasant street at dusk.  The butler came back and murmured something close to Tom’s ear, whereupon Tom frowned, pushed back his chair, and without a word went inside. As if his absence quickened something within her, Daisy leaned forward again, her voice glowing and singing.
Speaker: Narrator
